source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_043_chunk4
evidence_span: The best-estimate correlation for oxide thickness versus rod average burnup for the high-tin cladding in Reactor A is presented in Fig. 4

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_043_chunk4
evidence_span: The data points associated with Variants 1, 2, and 5 fall close to the high-tin curve in Fig. 4

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_043_chunk4
evidence_span: The data points for the low-tin Variants 3 and 4 fall below the curve, confirming the in-PWR benefit of low-tin material indicated by the 633 K water autoclave results

evidence_span: At a burnup of about 35 GWd/MTU, the low-tin Zircaloy-4 has oxide thickness values 30 to 40% lower than those for high-tin cladding

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_043_chunk4
evidence_span: no significant effect of the annealing parameter variation (over the range studied) is seen in the in-reactor oxide thickness measurements for either group of cladding

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_043_chunk4
evidence_span: The long-term water autoclave weight gain data and in-PWR oxide thickness measurement data presented in this paper demonstrate the improvement in the uniform corrosion resistance of Zircaloy-4 with a decrease in the tin content of the material

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_043_chunk4
evidence_span: The extent of improvement appears to be greater in-reactor than what is indicated by the 633 K water autoclave test results

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_043_chunk4
evidence_span: The nitrogen concentration for the variants used in the current investigation are listed in Table 1 and are fairly constant at 14 to 27 ppm

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_043_chunk4
evidence_span: Hydrogen uptake data presented in Table 2 indicate that the variation of tin level within the Zircaloy-4 composition range does not alter the hydrogen uptake significantly

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_043_chunk4
evidence_span: The small variation in hydrogen uptake fraction values listed in Table 2 is considered to be within the experimental measurement accuracy

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_043_chunk4
evidence_span: The hydrogen uptake value for autoclaved specimens listed in Table 2 is higher than the upper limit on hydrogen uptake (18%) observed in PWRs

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_043_chunk4
evidence_span: upper limit on hydrogen uptake (18%) observed in PWRs

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_043_chunk4
evidence_span: The hydrogen generated by the corrosion process builds up in a static autoclave and, thereby, the hydrogen uptake by the metal in a static autoclave is higher

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_043_chunk4
evidence_span: Under the flow conditions of a refreshed autoclave or a PWR, a part of the generated hydrogen is swept away by the coolant flow and the hydrogen pickup fraction for the metal is lower than that in a static autoclave

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_043_chunk5
evidence_span: The hydrogen migration from the water/oxide interface to the metal/oxide interface is probably by the migration of H+ ions (protons) along the oxide grain boundaries [47].

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_043_chunk5
evidence_span: As the oxide porosity increases with the increase in the oxide thickness, the mode of hydrogen transport through the oxide layer is expected to change.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_043_chunk5
evidence_span: This argument suggests that a replacement of a Zr4+ ion by a trivalent tin ion would increase the chance of hydrogen migration towards the metal. This will lead to a higher hydrogen uptake fraction with increasing tin content.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_043_chunk5
evidence_span: The tin range investigated in the current work is probably not large enough to observe this change in the hydrogen uptake fraction.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_043_chunk5
evidence_span: It is also possible that the tin level may influence the solubility of iron and chromium in Zircaloy-4 [28].

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_043_chunk5
evidence_span: The variation of tin level in Zircaloy-4, therefore, may affect the extent of the secondphase particle precipitation.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_043_chunk5
evidence_span: A change in the size and volume fraction of second-phase particles may change the short-circuit transport paths for electrons and, thereby, affect the hydrogen transport.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_043_chunk5
evidence_span: The autoclave corrosion weight gain data presented in Fig. 1 show the following trend in descending order of weight gain: Variant 5 (highest weight gain), Variants 1 and 2 together, and Variants 4 and 3 (with the lowest weight gain).

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_043_chunk5
evidence_span: It is to be noted that the difference in weight gain between Variants 5, 1, and 2 is small.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_043_chunk5
evidence_span: The in-PWR oxide thickness measurements (Fig. 4) for the same cladding variants rank essentially in the same order as the autoclave measurements.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_043_chunk5
evidence_span: In-PWR measurements seem to segregate into two groups. One group is the high-tin data for Variants 1, 2, and 5, and the other group is the low-tin data of Variants 3 and 4.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_043_chunk5
evidence_span: This data comparison supports the suggestion [36] that a long-term 633 K water autoclave corrosion test is a good screening test for ranking the in-PWR corrosion resistance of Zircaloy-4 variants.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_043_chunk5
evidence_span: A comparison of Variants 1 and 2 is useful to evaluate the effect of annealing process variation in high-tin Zircaloy-4.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_043_chunk5
evidence_span: The autoclave data in Fig. 1 shows no difference in weight gain for these two variants, while the in-PWR oxide thickness data (Fig. 4) show that a higher annealing parameter may improve the corrosion resistance slightly.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_043_chunk5
evidence_span: The autoclave data in Fig. 1 shows no difference in weight gain for these two variants, while the in-PWR oxide thickness data (Fig. 4) show that a higher annealing parameter may improve the corrosion resistance slightly.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_043_chunk5
evidence_span: A similar comparison for low-tin cladding variants shows that the lower annealing parameter, Variant 3, has slightly bcs ecav  hilxihis 4) show no effect of annealing process variation.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_043_chunk5
evidence_span: These comparisons show that any efect of annealing parameter variation (within the investigated range) on the corrosion rate, if it exists, is minor.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_043_chunk5
evidence_span: Relative insensitivity of cladding corrosion to annealing parameter variation in the range of approximately 1 to 4 × 10^-17 h (with Q/R = 40000 K) is consistent with the results reported by Garzarolli et al. [5].

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_043_chunk5
evidence_span: Reactor A has a nominal coolant inlet temperature of about 569 K and operated with reactor cycle lengths of from about a year to 18 months.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_043_chunk5
evidence_span: Reactor B's coolant inlet temperature was slightly lower, at about 563 K.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_043_chunk5
evidence_span: Reactor A and B both had an average subchannel coolant mass velocity of about 3730 Kg/m²s

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_043_chunk5
evidence_span: The ESCORE PWR corrosion model describes corrosion as a two-stage process. An initial period of nonlinear time dependence (pre-transition) is followed by a period of linear time dependence (post-transition).

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_043_chunk5
evidence_span: The thickness at transition is dependent on temperature at the metal oxide interface and generally lies in the range of 2 to 3 μm for the oxide thicknesses of interest.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_043_chunk5
evidence_span: Subset A, Reactor A, 3 cycles, 10 rods, 37.3 to 48.1 GWd/MTU, high tin content, EPB fabrication, 1.31 normalized pre-exponential multiplier

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_043_chunk5
evidence_span: Subset A, Reactor A, 2 cycles, 8 rods, 22.5 to 31.3 GWd/MTU, high tin content, EPB fabrication, 1.03 normalized pre-exponential multiplier

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_043_chunk5
evidence_span: Subset A, Reactor A, 3 cycles, 5 rods, 45.4 to 48.1 GWd/MTU, intermediate tin content, EPB fabrication, 1.08 normalized pre-exponential multiplier

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_043_chunk6
evidence_span: Subsets A and E are expected to be predicted by essentially the same pre-exponential term if there was no difference in the material characteristics between these two groups of fuel cladding.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_043_chunk6
evidence_span: Because Subset A was fabricated much earlier than Subset E, the cladding for Subset A is believed to offer less corrosion resistance than Subset E.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_043_chunk6
evidence_span: Subset E is corroding less rapidly than Subset A because of its improved fabrication

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_043_chunk6
evidence_span: The in-PWR corrosion resistance of Zircaloy-4 at high burnups improves by 30 to $40 \%$ EPY when the tin content is reduced to the lower limit of the ASTM composition range.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_043_chunk6
evidence_span: Based on the autoclave test results, tin level within the examined range does not appear to affect the hydrogen uptake in Zircaloy-4.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_043_chunk6
evidence_span: The pre-exponential multiplier for low-tin cladding was found to vary within the range of 71 to $74 \%$ of the high-tin cladding.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_043_chunk6
evidence_span: For intermediate-tin cladding, the multiplier was about $82 \%$ of that for the high-tin cladding.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_043_chunk6
evidence_span: Results of $6 3 3 \mathrm { K }$ long-term water autoclave tests correlate well with the in-PWR cladding corrosion resistance of the investigated cladding variants.

evidence_span: Sandvik Special Metals (SSM) for supplying the tubes with different fabrication histories

evidence_span: hydrogen analyses

evidence_span: autoclave testing

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_043_chunk8
evidence_span: Assuming that the average valancy of Sn is 3+, for 100 g of 1.3% Sn, 3.29 x 10^21 additional vacancies are introduced in the oxide phase.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_043_chunk8
evidence_span: For 1.5% Sn, the corresponding number is 3.8 x 10^21.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_043_chunk8
evidence_span: The number of vacancies in oxygen deficient zirconium oxide (ZrO2-δ) on 100g of Zirconium at 300°C is estimated to be 6.86 x 10^20.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_043_chunk8
evidence_span: The observed effect of tin level on the uniform corrosion resistance of Zircaloy-4 is consistent with an average valancy of Sn atoms dissolved in ZrO2 to be lower than four.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_043_chunk8
evidence_span: Therefore it is possible to associate the lower corrosion resistance of high-tin Zircaloy-4 with the introduction of additional vacancies in the oxide due to the tin addition to zirconium.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_043_chunk9
evidence_span: A pressurized water reactor (PWR) facility has been used to determine the effects of high (4 to 4.5 ppm) lithium on the corrosion behavior of Zircaloy-4 cladding material exposed to nucleate boiling (1% void) and to one-phase cooling conditions.

conditions.medium: PWR coolant with high lithium (4 to 4.5 ppm)

evidence_span: The test employed four fuel rod segments, base-irradiated to an average burnup of 28.5 MWd/kg UO2 in a commercial power plant, and with average initial oxide layers of either 10, 20, or 40 μm respectively.

evidence_span: The test employed four fuel rod segments, base-irradiated to an average burnup of 28.5 MWd/kg UO2 in a commercial power plant, and with average initial oxide layers of either 10, 20, or 40 μm respectively.

evidence_span: A common practice in operating pressurized water reactors (PWRs) is to maintain the coolant pH at 300°C at 6.9 in order to reduce the formation of crud on the fuel rods and thereby limit activation of the primary circuit.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_043_chunk9
evidence_span: An increasing number of utilities are adopting even higher pH levels as a consequence of solubility studies [1,2] that indicate that optimum pH300 lies in the 7.2 to 7.4 range.

evidence_span: Lithium (Li), a commonly used alkalizing agent has been shown to enhance the corrosion rate of Zircaloy in out-of-pile studies performed with concentrated solutions.
